headlines.headline: 'Don't end up like us, please'

features.summary: Martin Freeborn's wife, Helen, lost her fight against Covid at the Royal London Hospital, where staff are struggling to cope with rising admissions.

media.title: 'Don't end up like us, please'

synopses.short: Covid-19: 'Don't end up like us, please'
synopses.long:
Cases of coronavirus have fallen by almost a quarter across the UK in the last week, showing that the current lockdown is having an effect. But hospital admissions are still rising. 

Ten hospital trusts across England have reported having no spare critical care beds - despite extra capacity being added.  

The BBC's Clive Myrie has been to the Royal London Hospital and spent time with staff struggling to cope, as well as families experiencing the grief this pandemic is causing.
synopses.medium: Martin Freeborn's wife, Helen, lost her fight against Covid at the Royal London Hospital, where staff are struggling to cope with rising admissions.

media.caption: Martin Freeborn's wife, Helen, died from Covid at the Royal London Hospital: 'Don't end up like us, please'

headlines.headline: Conquering K2 in winter 'together'

features.summary: The BBC speaks to Nirmal Purja, from the team of the first climbers to reach the K2 summit in winter.

media.title: Conquering K2 in winter 'together'

synopses.long: A team of Nepalese climbers have become the first ever to summit the worldâ€™s second highest mountain K2 in winter. K2, along the Pakistan-China border, is notoriously challenging with high winds and sub-zero temperatures One of the leading members of the team is a former Gurkha and British special forces soldier Nirmal Purja. He spoke to BBC Pakistan correspondent Secunder Kermani.
synopses.medium: The BBC speaks to Nirmal Purja, one of the team of Nepalese climbers who made history by climbing to the K2 summit in winter for the first time.

media.caption: The first people to conquer the K2 summit in winter months

headlines.headline: The rise of the racism exposÃ© page

features.summary: 'Truth pages', where students share their experiences of racism, have been on appearing on social media since the killing of George Floyd.

media.title: The rise of the racism exposÃ© page

synopses.short: Racism in education: How 'truth pages' helped students fight back
synopses.long:
The killing of George Floyd was a catalyst moment for social justice movements across the world. But after the coronavirus pandemic worsened some of those movements were pushed aside.

One which hasnâ€™t is an online reckoning orchestrated by students, known as 'Truth Pages'. In the summer following George Floydâ€™s death, racism exposÃ© pages began springing up across both sides of the Atlantic, primarily on Instagram, allowing Black, Asian and minority ethnic students to share their experiences online.

The result was a wave of call to actions, some more successful than others, enlisting the cooperation of institutions in tackling racism and racial inequality.

The BBCâ€™s Lorna Acquah investigates the racism experienced by students in the UK and the US and how the movement snowballed.

Filmed and edited by Samantha Everett
Illustrations by ZoÃ« Slatter
synopses.medium: 'Truth pages', where students share their experiences of racism, have been on appearing on social media since the killing of George Floyd.

media.caption: From being an â€˜angry blackâ€™ to threats of being lynched, we examine a reckoning that took social media by storm

headlines.headline: The road back to Wuhan

features.summary: The BBC's Stephen McDonell visits Wuhan ahead of the anniversary of the world's first Covid-19 lockdown.

media.title: The road back to Wuhan

synopses.short: Covid-19: The road back to Wuhan
synopses.long:
BBC China correspondent Stephen McDonell has taken a road trip back to the Chinese city of Wuhan, as it nears the anniversary on 23 January of the world's first Covid-19 lockdown.

The virus was first detected in Wuhan in late 2019 before it spiralled into a global pandemic and turned the city into a ghost town with streets empty of residents and vehicles.

The lockdown was lifted in April and our correspondent returned to see how Wuhan and the surrounding province of Hubei are faring.

Filmed and edited by Edward Lawrence.

Producer: Lan Pan
synopses.medium: The BBC's Stephen McDonell visits Wuhan ahead of the anniversary of the world's first Covid-19 lockdown.

media.caption: The BBC's Stephen McDonell visited Wuhan ahead of the anniversary of the world's first Covid-19 lockdown

indexImage.altText: The BBC's Stephen McDonell visits Wuhan ahead of the anniversary of the world's first Covid-19 lockdown.
